docs.lead_paragraph: ATTENTION, shoppers: Some of America's biggest banks think it is time you stopped foraging around for necessities like credit cards, mortgages, insurance and checking accounts and just got all those financial goodies in one place: Theirs. Big bank mergers are afoot -- linking titans like BankAmerica with Nationsbank, Banc One with First Chicago and Citicorp with Travelers Group -- and one of the Big Ideas behind them is that consumers will embrace the concept of one-stop shopping for financial services. Other companies, like Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, and Merrill Lynch, the nation's leading brokerage firm, are pursuing similar strategies.

headline.main: How Big Banks See the World

docs.abstract: Big bank mergers taking place recently have been fueled by idea that consumers will embrace concept of one-stop shopping for financial services; some consumers buy into this, especially those willing to pay extra for convenience of getting one financial statement a month that neatly ties their far-flung money management needs into one package; but savvy consumers willing to shop around can unearth much better deals than those offered by expanding giants; megabankers are heartened by demographics of sitution, noting that one-stop shopping appeals to people younger than 40; but megabankers must also contend with fact that same under-40 crowd is most adept at using Internet technology that can make one-stop shopping much less necessary; drawings; charts (L)

byline.original: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and SAUL HANSELL

docs.lead_paragraph: Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn and the New York State Nurses Association have reached a tentative agreement to end a three-week strike prompted in part by a proposal for shift changes for some nurses, officials on both sides said yesterday. Details of the agreement, reached early in the morning after talks ran through the night, were not available from either side. But the tentative deal was confirmed by Nancy Webber, a spokeswoman for the nurses' association, and Vicki Ciampa, a spokeswoman for Maimonides in Borough Park.

headline.main: Nurses and Maimonides Medical Center Reach Tentative Deal to End a 3-Week Strike

docs.abstract: Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn and New York State Nurses Assn reach tentative agreement to end three-week strike prompted in part by proposal for shift changes for some nurses; members of association will vote on agreement on Apr 21, but it is unclear when they will return to work; strike illuminates growing pains in health-care system at time when private and government insurance programs are cutting reimbursement rates, causing some hospitals to demand concessions from workers in effort to keep costs down (M)
docs.snippet: Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn and the New York State Nurses Association have reached a tentative agreement to end a three-week strike prompted in part by a proposal for shift changes for some nurses, officials on both sides said yesterday.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: JOEL GORDES, an energy consultant, believes that Connecticut's multibillion-dollar insurance industry has a choice: face possible financial ruin from losses due to more frequent and severe storms, droughts and wildfires or commit some of the industry's considerable resources to efforts to stem global warming. Mr. Gordes is a consultant to Dr. Jeremy Leggett, formerly of Greenpeace International, and now of Solar Century in Britain. Dr. Leggett began the discussions about climate change between insurers and environmentalists in Europe.

headline.main: Q&A/Joel Gordes; Insurers, Risk and the Global Climate

docs.abstract: Interview with Joel Gordes, energy consultant, on his effort to persuade insurance industry to help stem global warming and resulting rise in insurance risk; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1985, the Columbia Falls Aluminum Company wrung a 15 percent pay cut from employees in return for an apparent will-o'-the-wisp: a share of profits from an aluminum refinery that was a perennial money loser. Brack W. Duker, the corporate executive who had just bought the refinery from the Atlantic Richfield Company for a symbolic $1, held out a firm promise, many workers recall. If the aluminum market ever recovered, Mr. Duker assured them as he lobbied for the plan, ''a dollar in your pocket is a dollar in mine.''

headline.main: A Broken Pact and a $97 Million Payday

docs.abstract: Article recounts David-versus-Goliath business tale pitting Roberta Gilmore, company accountant, against her employer, Columbia Falls Aluminum Co of Montana; Gilmore was fired when she challenged company's bookkeeping practices; at issue was profit-sharing pledge made by company in return for 15 percent pay cut agreed to by employees; Gilmore discovered that profits were being funneled to offshore banks rather than given to employees; Brack W Duker, head of company, threatened to close plant, frightening employees into asking Gilmore to drop her suit; she perservered and Duker caved in after Gilmore's lawyers found documents spelling out profit-sharing arrangement, and internal memo sent anonymously directed them to Caribbean shell company to which profits had been directed; as result of suit brought by Gilmore, company agreed to pay workers $97 million; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Newt Gingrich and House Republican leaders may draft their own version of tobacco legislation, a spokesman for a powerful House committee said today. Mr. Gingrich said he believed that the Senate's tobacco bill, proposed by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, was too liberal to win approval in the House. He said it was ''not a Republican bill,'' but ''a very liberal, big government, big bureaucracy bill.''

headline.main: House Republican Leaders May Propose Tobacco Legislation

docs.abstract: Speaker Newt Gingrich and House Republican leaders say they may draft their own version of tobacco legislation; Gingrich says Senate's tobacco bill, proposed by Sen John McCain, is too liberal to win approval in House (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Walk around Harlem and it is hard to find a person who, for better or worse, has not been cared for at Harlem Hospital Center. It is a matter of pride and history. James Baldwin and Tito Puente were born there. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was taken there -- doctors had to crack his sternum with a hammer and chisel -- when a deranged woman plunged a knife into his chest in 1958. ''This is like a mother figure,'' said Bruce Wright, the fiery former state judge, who was walking by the hospital the other day and stopped for a moment to remember having his tonsils out there at age 8. He is now 80.

headline.main: Harlem Hospital Is Symbol Of Troubled Public System

docs.abstract: Harlem Hospital Center, long a community fixture, is losing patients faster than any other New York City public hospital as private hospitals woo Medicaid patients they once shunned; loss of patients has forced hospital to cut half its beds over last five years, leading Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani to target hospital for big layoffs; union workers, Democratic politicians and advocates for poor hold layoffs are step in what could become downward spiral in quality and availability of health care for poor; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. ''The Nature of Diamonds,'' an exhibition exploring all aspects of the mineral, from its geologic origins to its popularity as an adornment to its modern uses in technology and research. Through April 26. Admission is by timed ticket only. ''Africa: Explorations and Expeditions,'' featuring firsthand accounts of European and American exploration from the 18th century on, as depicted in selections from the museum's rare-book collection. Through Sept. 30. Opening tomorrow, ''Kings, Chiefs and Women of Power,'' works by the photographer Phyllis Galembo, featuring portraits of Nigeria's traditional leaders. Through June 28. A symposium titled ''The Value of Plants, Animals, and Microbes to Human Health'' will take place all day today and tomorrow. Call for schedule and fees. ''Indigenous Peoples' Celebration,'' featuring theater, video, music, dance and art. Tomorrow and Sunday: at 1 P.M., ''Kumbharwada, Bombay'' (1996), a video documentary about a thriving potters' colony; at 2 and 3:30 P.M., ''Nepali by Heart,'' Sherry Onna Handlin will discuss the culture, life and land of Nepal; at 2:30 and 4 P.M., ''Songs and Dances of Nepal,'' a performance of traditional music and dance. Free with museum admission. Permanent displays include the dinosaur and fossil halls and the Imax films ''Cosmic Voyage,'' ''Whales'' and the recently opened ''Titanica,'' which chronicles the construction, sinking, exploration and excavation of the Titanic. In the Imax Theater on Fridays and Saturdays at 9 P.M., ''Led Zeppelin in 3-D'' and ''Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' '' in 3-D. Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.

docs.lead_paragraph: A dental surgeon spent an hour in my jaw and sent me off with a prescription. I presented it at a pharmacy. The pharmacist presented me with 28 pills. ''That will be $72,'' he said.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column describes his personal encounter with health insurance abuses and ripoffs, citing cost of his prescription for antibiotics following dental work, and Medicare's refusal to cover laboratory work a doctor thought was necessary (M)
docs.snippet: A dental surgeon spent an hour in my jaw and sent me off with a prescription. I presented it at a pharmacy.     The pharmacist presented me with 28 pills. ''That will be $72,'' he said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Come to fast-growing Idaho, the people behind the prosperous new economy here like to say, and you will find a nearly crime-free state with no visible poor people. With little patience for investing in social welfare or giving criminals time off for good behavior, state leaders here have charted a course that fits Idaho's political personality. And if they are filling up prisons at an exceedingly high rate while reducing welfare rolls to an astonishing level, that is the plan and goal.

headline.main: As Idaho Booms, Prisons Fill And Spending on Poor Lags

docs.abstract: Idaho's booming economy seemingly comes at expense of its poor; Idaho leads nation in reducing its welfare rolls, and it also leads nation in proportion of abused or neglected children; crime is low, but prisons are filling faster than ever; people are locked up for crimes that most states do not even consider felonies, and Idaho is one of few states to eliminate parole for good behavior; experts say trends in Idaho bear watching by other states that have reduced spending on basic welfare and education needs of poor children while pouring dollars into new prisons; Alan Minskoff, editor of Boise Magazine, attributes state's harsh policies toward poor to fact that Idaho has become what he calls a monarchy, with all but one statewide officeholder belonging to Republican Party; beyond political philosophies, some experts say Idaho is making bad investment for taxpayers; state spends $17 per person on overall child welfare, and five times that much on each prisoner; Idaho is one of only three states that count Social Security disability payments as income that would disqualify someone from welfare; even Idaho's Governor, Phil Batt, who supports course his state has chosen, recently warned that state policies may be too hard on children and poor, and too quick to put people in prison; photos; chart (L)
docs.snippet: Come to fast-growing Idaho, the people behind the prosperous new economy here like to say, and you will find a nearly crime-free state with no visible poor people.    With little patience for investing in social welfare or giving criminals  time off...

docs.lead_paragraph: Host Is Homeless TOM SNYDER became a talk-show host without a studio yesterday, in a city not his own. Mr. Snyder's California-based ''Late Late Show,'' on CBS, is scheduled to originate from New York next week. Mr. Snyder had planned to do the program from the vacant penthouse apartment that DONALD J. TRUMP and MARLA MAPLES never moved into (they divorced instead). The apartment, on the 52d floor of the Trump International Hotel and Towers at 1 Central Park West, has a backdrop a talk-show host would love: the floor-to-ceiling plate-glass windows have postcard-perfect views of the city (including an unobstructed view of the G.E. Building, the headquarters of NBC, where Mr. Snyder used to work).
docs.abstract: Upcoming programs of Tom Snyder's California-based Late Late Show on CBS are scheduled to originate from New York City; chef Pamela Morgan, at fund-raising lunch for Women's Leadership Forum, gives Hillary Rodham Clinton copy of her soon-to-be published cookbook; director Nora Ephron says lost dog rescued near Brooklyn-Queens Expressway exit will have walk-on part in her new film, You've Got Mail; photos (M)
